stepAnswer: A permutation of $$n$$ objects refers to arranging all $$n$$ objects in a specific order, while choosing $$r$$ objects from $$n$$ refers to selecting $$r$$ objects without regard to the order.
stepTitle: Describe how the permutation of $$n$$ objects differs from the permutation of choosing $$r$$ objects from a set of $$n$$ objects.
answerLatex: A permutation of $$n$$ objects refers to arranging all $$n$$ objects in a specific order, while choosing $$r$$ objects from $$n$$ refers to selecting $$r$$ objects without regard to the order.
choices: A permutation of $$n$$ objects refers to arranging all $$n$$ objects in a specific order, while choosing $$r$$ objects from $$n$$ refers to selecting $$r$$ objects without regard to the order.
A permutation of $$n$$ objects involves selecting $$r$$ objects in a specific order, while the permutation of choosing $$r$$ objects from $$n$$ involves arranging all $$n$$ objects.
A permutation of $$n$$ objects is a selection of $$r$$ objects, and the permutation of choosing $$r$$ objects from $$n$$ means arranging them in order.
A permutation of $$n$$ objects is the same as choosing $$r$$ objects from a set of $$n$$ objects.
